div.p: STEW, a ſmall kind of fiſh-pond, the peculiar uſe of which is to maintain fiſh, and keep them in readineſs for the daily uſe of the family, &c.

Stews (from the French estuves, i. e. thermae, balneum), thoſe places which were permitted in England to women of profeſſed incontinency, and that for hire would proſtitute their bodies to all comers; ſo called, becauſe disſolute perſons are wont to prepare them ſelves for venereous acts by bathing ; and hot baths were by Homer reckoned among the effeminate fort of pleaſures. Theſe ſtews were ſuppressed by King Hen. VIII. about the year 1546.
